It doesn't work for you here because you do not have the docker.service file as a file to watch in the docker.service.running block.  We had a similar problem for the Kubelet in this area that I have a fix for here:
https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/10492

I think you can get rid of fix-service-docker and just add the watch on the file or a require on the file when running in a systemd setup.

The root issue that caused me to just move this out of salt is this one: https://github.com/saltstack/salt/issues/16778

Salt won't do a daemon-reload out-of-the-box, by design.  This was not what I was expecting.

I can definitely add the extra watch, but it won't work if e.g. docker has already been loaded by systemd.
Interesting.  I wonder if I didnt encounter this before because Fedora came with a .service file as part of the yum install of docker.
